channel.title: Ruby
channel.description:
Hey guys,
I was just wondering, how could Ruby be used? And is it good (better than java)?

item.title: Ruby
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“The Outsider, post:18, topic:424485”]What kind of things are programmed in Lisp/Clojure? Never heard of them before.[/quote]there was a period of time where they were used for AI, but that boom died after people started accomplishing the same things with imperative languages. overall, most lisp dialects are general purpose and can be used for anything really… although you do sometimes get dialects specialised for one job (the guys that made Crash Bandicoot and Jak and Daxter used a Lisp dialect for the scripting side of their engine, Ypsilon Scheme was written as an addition to a game engine and is fast) and the Movitz dialect of Common Lisp which targets the Movitz OS project’s runtime Muerte, which runs on top of a small assembly core and allows the majority of things in it to be written in pure Lisp. the emacs text editor uses Lisp for scripting too, and is pretty damn good for Lisp development as a result.

there’s also a few nooks and crannies where you’ll find Lisp used tdday, but it’s becoming slowly a language of the past which projects like newLISP and Clojure (and certain CL/Scheme dialects) aim to defy, and you’ll find the majority of Lisp programmers both seasoned and fresh only use it because they like it. hell, Lisp is great when you beat the parentheses and weird abstractions

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @baddy351 baddy351
item.description:
@baddy351 wrote:

Scheme is nice, I have been learning it.
Clojure is ugly… lua is lua…
Oh and lots of things are programmed in Lisp, it is the 2nd oldest still used programming language, simple yet powerful (Specifically Scheme).

item.title: Ruby
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Rix_, post:14, topic:424485”][quote author=runewings317 link=topic=527141.msg3842130#msg3842130 date=1323316340]Link me some info? Like the site? I googled it and I didn’t get anything… Lol
[/quote]
Assuming you already have experience with Java, you should check out Clojure (a dialect of Lisp that runs on the JVM).

en.wikipedia.org

Clojure

Clojure ( /ˈkloʊʒɜːr/, like "closure") is a dialect of the Lisp programming language. Clojure is a general-purpose programming language with an emphasis on functional programming. It runs on the Java virtual machine and the Common Language Runtime. There is a dialect, developed in lockstep with Clojure, called ClojureScript, that compiles to ECMAScript 3. Like other Lisps, Clojure treats code as data and has a macro system. The current development process is community-driv Clojure encourages immu...


http://clojure.org/getting_started[/quote]my only dislike for Clojure comes from shit like

(defn fact [n]
  (loop [nn n acc 1]
    (if (zero? nn)
      acc
      (recur (dec nn) (* acc nn))))

ugly LOOP and RECUR forms…

much nicer in Scheme or CL

(define (fact n) ; CL: (defun fact (n) (if (= n 0) ; or (zero? n) 1 (* n (fact (- n 1)))))
(apparently Scheme code highlighting is fucked, nothing shows up)

Clojure’s interop is nice, although most Scheme and Common Lisp dialects (especially those using C as intermediate code) provide great C/C++ code interfacing.

Read full topic

item.title: Ruby
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Lisp (programming language)

Lisp (historically, LISP) is a family of computer programming languages with a long history and a distinctive, fully parenthesized prefix notation. Originally specified in 1958, Lisp is the second-oldest high-level programming language in widespread use today. Only Fortran is older, by one year. Lisp has changed since its early days, and many dialects have existed over its history. Today, the best known general-purpose Lisp dialects are Common Lisp and Scheme. Lisp was originally created as a pra...


http://groups.engin.umd.umich.edu/CIS/course.des/cis400/lisp/lisp.html
http://common-lisp.info/

Read full topic
